title: 115_hr3596
content: The "Rightsizing Pension Premiums Act of 2017" may be cited as the short title for this Act. It aims to adjust pension premiums accordingly. The "Rightsizing Pension Premiums Act of 2017" adjusts annual premium rates for single-employer plans based on the PBGC funded percentage. The "Rightsizing Pension Premiums Act of 2017" adjusts annual premium rates for single-employer plans based on the PBGC funded percentage by providing an additional premium to participants based on unfunded vested benefits. The "Rightsizing Pension Premiums Act of 2017" adjusts premium rates for single-employer plans based on PBGC funded percentage, providing an additional premium to participants with unfunded vested benefits. The "Rightsizing Pension Premiums Act of 2017" adjusts premium rates for single-employer plans based on PBGC funded percentage, providing an additional premium to participants with unfunded vested benefits equal to $9 for each $1,000 of unfunded vested benefits, multiplied by the number of participants in the plan. The "Rightsizing Pension Premiums Act of 2017" provides an additional premium to participants in single-employer plans with a funded percentage of at least 90% but less than 100%. The premium is calculated as $64 plus an extra amount determined by dividing $28 for each $1,000 of unfunded vested benefits by the number of participants in the plan. The "Rightsizing Pension Premiums Act of 2017" provides an additional premium for participants in CSEC plans or single-employer plans maintained by small employers. The premium includes a base amount of $19 per participant, plus an extra premium calculated based on the unfunded vested benefits under the plan from the preceding plan year. The "Rightsizing Pension Premiums Act of 2017" introduces a small employer premium phase-out for single-employer plans with 500 to 600 employees. The annual premium rate is based on the number of participants in the plan and additional factors. The "Rightsizing Pension Premiums Act of 2017" introduces a small employer premium phase-out for single-employer plans with 500 to 600 employees. The annual premium rate for participants is calculated based on specific criteria. The "Rightsizing Pension Premiums Act of 2017" introduces a small employer premium phase-out for single-employer plans with 500 to 600 employees. The annual premium rate payable by such plans is based on the applicable percentage, which is the ratio of the number of employees exceeding 500 to 100. In the case of a multiple employer plan, the annual premium rate payable to the corporation is determined differently. The premium rate payable to the corporation for basic benefits guaranteed under this title is determined based on the annual premiums that would be imposed on each separate plan in accordance with this section. The determination of annual premiums for separate plans under this section is based on whether an employer is a small employer, with a special rule for small employers with 25 or fewer employees limiting additional premiums to $5 per participant in the plan. For plan years starting after 2018, wage indexing of certain dollar amounts is required based on the national average wage index from the preceding two calendar years. For plan years starting after 2018, certain dollar amounts are adjusted based on the national average wage index from the preceding two calendar years. The term 'small employer' refers to an employer with 500 or fewer employees at the beginning of the plan year. If an amount is not a multiple of $1, it is rounded to the nearest dollar. The term 'multiple employer plan' refers to a single-employer plan maintained by more than one employer. The term 'single-employer pension insurance program funded percentage' for a fiscal year is the ratio of the value of assets held by the corporation available for the payment of guaranteed benefits. The term 'unfunded vested benefits' refers to the excess of liabilities attributable to guaranteed benefits on the last day of the fiscal year, as defined in section 210(f) for a CSEC plan. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to address excess funding liability in pension plans and individuals participating in multiple plans. The Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include paragraph (9) after subparagraph (C), effective for plan years starting after December 31, 2017. SEC. 3. Correction of the budget effects of premium changes. The provision excludes any changes in premiums to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation from budget calculations in the Senate and House of Representatives for points of order under the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. Congress adopts these provisions as part of its rulemaking power. The Senate and House of Representatives have the power to make rules, which supersede other rules if inconsistent. Each House can change its rules regarding procedures at any time.
